unnormalised: **EV Charging Gets a Festive Boost Ahead of Onam!**
normalised: **Electric Vehicle Charging Gets a Festive Boost Ahead of Onam!**

unnormalised: Bangalore, Aug 20 - Just in time for Onam celebrations, EV charging infrastructure is getting a much-needed upgrade! Imagine road tripping back home to Kerala for Onam, not worrying about finding a charging point in time for a delicious Onasadya. That's the dream, right?
normalised: Bangalore, August twenty - Just in time for Onam celebrations, electric vehicle charging infrastructure is getting a much needed upgrade! Imagine road tripping back home to Kerala for Onam, not worrying about finding a charging point in time for a delicious Onasadya. That's the dream, right?

unnormalised: Ola Electric is reportedly planning to install fast chargers at key highway pit stops, connecting major cities like Chennai and Coimbatore to Bangalore. Tata Power is also expanding its network, focusing on tier-2 cities where the demand for EVs is growing faster than you can say "biryani."
normalised: Ola Electric is reportedly planning to install fast chargers at key highway pit stops, connecting major cities like Chennai and Coimbatore to Bangalore. Tata Power is also expanding its network, focusing on tier two cities where the demand for electric vehicles is growing faster than you can say "biryani."

unnormalised: The Indian Institute of Technology, Madras (IIT-M) is researching next-gen battery tech that promises faster charging and longer ranges. Expect to see EVs zipping around, covering 600 km on a single charge sometime soon.
normalised: The Indian Institute of Technology, Madras (I I T-M) is researching next generation battery tech that promises faster charging and longer ranges. Expect to see electric vehicles zipping around, covering six hundred kilometer on a single charge sometime soon.

unnormalised: But the real question is, will these chargers be reliable? Remember the last time your phone died during a family video call? No one wants that frustration on a long drive. Hopefully, these upgrades mean fewer charging woes and more time enjoying the festival. Initial reports suggest charging prices could be around Rs. 15-20 per unit. Fingers crossed!
normalised: But the real question is, will these chargers be reliable? Remember the last time your phone died during a family video call? No one wants that frustration on a long drive. Hopefully, these upgrades mean fewer charging woes and more time enjoying the festival. Initial reports suggest charging prices could be around rupee fifteen to twenty per unit. Fingers crossed!
